title: Cycling in Hua Hin
text:
NEWSPAPER SECTION: LIFE | WRITER: PICHAYA SVASTI - + The "Ratchapak Bike and Concert: Gratitude to Motherland" cycling race will take place on the 126km route between Ratchapak Park and Jalaprathan Cement Factory and back to the park in Hua Hin district, Prachuap Khiri Khan, on Sept 12. 
Ratchapak Park 
The objectives are to raise funds to build Ratchapak Park, honour His Majesty the King and encourage people to exercise for good health. Winners will obtain royal trophies from HRH Crown Prince Maha Vajiralongkorn and his daughter HRH Princess Bajrakitiyabha. The Princess, along with invited guests, will ride bicycles on a 33km route from Cha-am Forest Park in Phetchaburi to downtown Hua Hin and the Ratchapak Park. 
After the race, participants will get the opportunity to plant golden shower trees in the park and also enjoy a free concert on Hua Hin beach. Singers on the list are Assanee and Wasant Chotikul, Billy Ogan, Pongpat Wachirabanjong, Academy Fantasia singers and many more. 
Application fee is 1,500 baht per person. Each contestant will receive a T-shirt, a cloth bag, entry into the concert and free beverages. Fruit fair in Nakhon Pathom 
Until Sept 13, the annual "Monthon Nakhon Chaisi Pomelo and Nakhon Pathom Fruits Fair" is being held at the Thai Imagery Museum in Nakhon Chaisi district, Nakhon Pathom. 
Nakhon Pathom has long-been well-known for two strains of pomelos -- khao nam phung and thongdee . Pomelos here taste good because the plants are grown in fertile soil in fruit orchards surrounded by water dykes. 
At the fair, there are exhibitions on agricultural knowledge and pomelo growing, a walking street, a bike lane and the sale of fruits, local handicrafts and goods. The highlight is an all-you-can-eat fruit buffet with pomelo, coconut fruit, guava and more for the price of 80 baht per person. 
Call the TAT local office on 034-752-847/8 or the TAT Call Centre on 1672. A cultural trip in Bangkok 
On Sept 12, TAT's Bangkok Office will host the "Walking Bangkok" trip called "Many Places: Temples, Palaces and Houses" for participants to learn about the history of the vicinity of the Phadung Krung Kasem canal, from 8.30am until 4.30pm. 
Participants must register at Parusakavan Palace near the Royal Plaza at 8.30am and start the study tour at the palace at 9am and then at the adjacent Police Museum. 
Morning activities include learning about the history of Chandrakasem Palace and paying respect to the statue of King Rama V. At 11.30am, participants will eat lunch at Nang Loeng Market. 
Afternoon activities include paying respect to the statue of Prince of Chumphon and visiting an old wooden cinema called Chalerm Thani and Wat Khae Nang Loeng: home of the statues of the late revered monk Luang Pu Thoop and the late actor Mitr Chaibancha. 
Participants will also take a boat ride at Government House pier to see various important places along the canals, such as Bobae Market, Phibultham Residence and the Hua Lamphong Railway Station, before finishing the day at the Floating Market. Visit www.Facebook.com/TATBANGKOK for information. Museum day in Ayutthaya 
On Sept 19, the Chao Sam Phraya National Museum in Ayutthaya will celebrate Thai Museums Day by hosting the "From Ratchaburana Temple to the Chao Sam Phraya National Museum" fair to educate the public about local history. 
Activities, including exhibitions and a lecture, will last from 8.30am until 3pm. The lecture, however, is limited to just 50 audience members. Call the museum on 035-241-587.
